messages.content:
You are a debugging assistant. You will be presented with a failing test, and tools (functions) to access the source code of the system under test (SUT). Your task is to provide a step-by-step explanation of how the bug occurred, based on the failing test and the information you retrieved using tests about the SUT. You will be given 9 chances to interact with functions to gather relevant information. An example answer would look like follows.

Title: Diagnosis of test `testGenerateURLFragment`
Details: The test `testGenerateURLFragment` checks whether HTML entities such as `"` are correctly escaped to their corresponding character by the `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` method. However, the test failure indicates that this is not the case. Following the execution path, we find that `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` is not escaping any HTML code; instead, it is using its input `toolTipText` as is. Consequently, un-escaped strings are being returned, which leads to the error demonstrated by the test.

After providing this diagnosis, you will be prompted to suggest which methods would be the best locations to be fixed. The answers should be in the form of `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` without commentary (one per line), as your answer will be automatically processed before finally being presented to the user.

The test `['com.google.javascript.jscomp.UnreachableCodeEliminationTest.testIssue311()']` failed.
The test looks like:

```java
252 :   public void testIssue311() {
253 :     test("function a(b) {\n" + // error occurred here
254 :          "  switch (b.v) {\n" +
255 :          "    case 'SWITCH':\n" +
256 :          "      if (b.i >= 0) {\n" +
257 :          "        return b.o;\n" +
258 :          "      } else {\n" +
259 :          "        return;\n" +
260 :          "      }\n" +
261 :          "      break;\n" +
262 :          "  }\n" +
263 :          "}",
264 :          "function a(b) {\n" +
265 :          "  switch (b.v) {\n" +
266 :          "    case 'SWITCH':\n" +
267 :          "      if (b.i >= 0) {\n" +
268 :          "        return b.o;\n" +
269 :          "      } else {\n" +
270 :          "      }\n" +
271 :          "  }\n" +
272 :          "}");
273 :   }
```

The passing test with the highest token similarity to the failing test looks like:

 ```None
```

 Functions covered by passing tests are less likely to be buggy.
It failed with the following error message and call stack:

```

      break;

	at com.google.javascript.jscomp.NodeUtil.removeChild(NodeUtil.java:1382)
	at com.google.javascript.jscomp.UnreachableCodeElimination.removeDeadExprStatementSafely(UnreachableCodeElimination.java:234)
	at com.google.javascript.jscomp.UnreachableCodeElimination.visit(UnreachableCodeElimination.java:105)
	at com.google.javascript.jscomp.NodeTraversal.traverseBranch(NodeTraversal.java:464)
```

Start by calling the `get_failing_tests_covered_classes` function.

The failing test `com.google.javascript.jscomp.UnreachableCodeEliminationTest.testIssue311()` is located in the `com.google.javascript.jscomp` package. It covers classes such as `LoggerErrorManager`, `SourceFile`, `ControlFlowAnalysis`, `NodeUtil`, `UnreachableCodeElimination`, `Compiler`, and others.

The failing test `com.google.javascript.jscomp.UnreachableCodeEliminationTest.testIssue311()` covers several methods in the `UnreachableCodeElimination` class such as:
- `tryRemoveUnconditionalBranching(com.google.javascript.rhino.Node)`
- `computeFollowing(com.google.javascript.rhino.Node)`
- `removeDeadExprStatementSafely(com.google.javascript.rhino.Node)`
- `visit(com.google.javascript.jscomp.NodeTraversal, com.google.javascript.rhino.Node, com.google.javascript.rhino.Node)`
- `UnreachableCodeElimination(com.google.javascript.jscomp.AbstractCompiler, boolean)`
- `enterScope(com.google.javascript.jscomp.NodeTraversal)`
- `process(com.google.javascript.rhino.Node, com.google.javascript.rhino.Node)`
- `exitScope(com.google.javascript.jscomp.NodeTraversal)`

messages.content:
The method `removeDeadExprStatementSafely(Node n)` in the `UnreachableCodeElimination` class is responsible for handling the removal of dead code statements. It checks the type of the node and performs specific actions based on the node type. The method `visit(NodeTraversal t, Node n, Node parent)` is invoked during the traversal of the AST nodes and calls `removeDeadExprStatementSafely(Node n)` to remove unreachable code statements.

Based on the code snippets, it seems that the issue might be related to the logic in the `removeDeadExprStatementSafely` method not correctly handling the case described in the failing test `testIssue311`. Further investigation is needed to pinpoint the exact cause of the failure.

Based on the available information, provide the signatures of the most likely culprit methods for the bug. Your answer will be processed automatically, so make sure to only answer with the accurate signatures of all likely culprits (in `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` format), without commentary (one per line).

It checks the type of the node and performs specific actions based on the node type. The method `visit(NodeTraversal t, Node n, Node parent)` is invoked during the traversal of the AST nodes and calls `removeDeadExprStatementSafely(Node n)` to remove unreachable code statements.
